questions.text: Mitochondrial matrix enzyme is? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Citrate synthase

 

Citrate synthase is an enzyme located in the mitochondrial matrix, where it catalyzes the first step of the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle, also known as the Krebs cycle. This step involves the condensation of oxaloacetate and acetyl-CoA to form citrate. The TCA cycle is a central metabolic pathway that plays a critical role in cellular respiration, generating energy through the oxidation of acetyl-CoA derived from carbohydrates, fats, and proteins.

 

 

Note – all the enzymes of TCA are in mitochondrial matrix except – Succinate dehydrogenase (present in inner mitochondrial membrane)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Monoamine oxidase: This enzyme is involved in the catabolism of monoamine neurotransmitters such as dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin. It is located on the outer mitochondrial membrane, not in the mitochondrial matrix.

 

Option C. ATP synthase: This enzyme complex is embedded in the inner mitochondrial membrane and is responsible for synthesizing ATP from ADP and inorganic phosphate during oxidative phosphorylation. It is part of the electron transport chain (ETC) as Complex V.

 

Option D. Catalase: Catalase is an enzyme that catalyzes the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide to water and oxygen. It is predominantly found in peroxisomes, not in the mitochondria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Citrate synthase is a key enzyme of the TCA cycle located in the mitochondrial matrix.

questions.text: The production of which of the following hormones is increased in obesity? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Insulin

 

In obesity, there is typically an increase in insulin production due to insulin resistance. This resistance at the cellular level leads to impaired glucose uptake by cells, prompting the pancreas to secrete more insulin in an attempt to maintain normal blood glucose levels—a state referred to as compensatory hyperinsulinemia. Over time, this can strain the pancreas and exacerbate metabolic issues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thyroxine: Thyroxine levels are generally not increased in obesity; thyroid function can sometimes be altered, but not in the manner of increased production directly due to obesity.

 

Option C. Growth hormone: Growth hormone levels are often decreased in obesity. Growth hormone has lipolytic effects, helping to break down fats, and its lower levels in obesity are associated with an adverse metabolic profile.

 

Option D. Adiponectin: This is a hormone produced by adipose tissue that enhances insulin sensitivity and has anti-inflammatory effects. Levels of adiponectin are typically lower in individuals with obesity, which contributes to increased insulin resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In obesity, insulin resistance occurring due defect at receptors which causes compensatory hyperinsulinemia. Thyroxine, growth hormone, and adiponectin have lipolytic effects, hence, their levels are reduced in obesity.

 

Reference - Harrison/Obesity

questions.text: Deficiency of which of the following causes increased glutamine in blood? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ornithine transcarbamoylase

 

Deficiency of ornithine transcarbamoylase is an X-linked genetic disorder known as ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency (OTC deficiency). This deficiency impairs the urea cycle's function, leading to the accumulation of ammonia and causing hyperammonemia. Elevated ammonia levels can indirectly affect glutamine metabolism, potentially leading to increased glutamine in the blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arginosuccinate lyase: Deficiency of arginosuccinate lyase is associated with argininosuccinic aciduria, a disorder that results in the accumulation of argininosuccinic acid and ammonia. However, this deficiency does not directly lead to increased glutamine levels.

 

Option B. Alpha-galactosidase-A: Deficiency of alpha-galactosidase-A is associated with Fabry disease, a lysosomal storage disorder. It does not lead to increased glutamine levels in the blood.

 

Option D. Arginase: Deficiency of arginase is associated with argininemia, a rare urea cycle disorder. Arginase deficiency leads to the accumulation of arginine and ammonia in the blood. As with OTC deficiency, elevated ammonia levels can indirectly affect glutamine metabolism, potentially leading to increased glutamine in the blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ornithine transcarbamoylase deficiency is a urea cycle disorder, which is inherited as an X-linked trait. Hyperammonemia Type II is characterized by OTC deficiency. Mothers also have hyperammonemia and an aversion to high protein diet. To reduce ammonia levels, glutamate combines with ammonia to form glutamine. Thus, elevated levels of ammonia are associated with high glutamine levels in CSF and blood.

 

Urea cycle disorders

questions.text: CT scan of a patient with laryngeal carcinoma is shown below. Single ipsilateral < 3cm node is seen. What is the staging? (INICET NOVEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. T4N1M0

The given CT image is consistent with a staging of T4N1M0. It depicts a large glottic-subglottic mass with massive cricoid and thyroid invasion and extra laryngeal spread indicating a T4 stage.

Above shown is CT scan of a 72-year-old patient with T4a laryngeal cancer (red arrows) showing a large extralaryngeal extension through the left side of the thyroid cartilage. Indication of primary total laryngectomy.

Other Options:

Option A. T1N0M0: Would indicate a tumor confined to one subsite with no lymph node involvement or distant metastasis, which does not correlate with the extensive involvement shown in the image.

Option C. T2N1M0: Suggests tumor involvement of adjacent subsites or impaired vocal cord mobility, which is less extensive than that shown.

Option D. T3N0M0: Indicates more advanced local disease than T2 but without the extensive extra-laryngeal spread or significant lymph node involvement shown in the image.

Educational Objective:

TNM STAGING FOR CA LARYNX:

T1 – Only 1 subsite (supraglottis/glottis/subglottis)

T2 – Involves adjacent subsites or sites, impaired vocal cord mobility.

T3 – Involving Pre-epiglottic space & post-cricoid area, fixed vocal cords.

T4a – Local invasion through thyroid cartilage or tissues beyond larynx

T4b – Invasion to distant places (prevertebral space, mediastinum, carotid, etc)

N0 – No cervical lymph nodes

N1 – Single ipsilateral < 3cm

N2 – Single ipsilateral 3-6cm / multiple ipsilateral, contralateral or bilateral < 6cm

N3 – Single or multiple nodes > 6cm

M0 – No metastasis

M1 – Metastasis present

Ref: Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 348

questions.text: A young patient presents in a multi-specialty hospital with sudden onset chest pain since 1 hour with ECG showing ST elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. What is the best treatment? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Primary Angioplasty

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presents with symptoms and ECG findings indicative of an acute inferior ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). The presence of ST elevation in leads II, III, and aVF confirms the diagnosis. Primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI), also known as primary angioplasty, is the best treatment for STEMI if it can be performed promptly. PCI is preferred because it directly opens the blocked coronary artery, restoring blood flow more quickly and effectively than thrombolytic therapy.

 

Note - If Primary PCI not possible or delayed due to some reasons then thrombolytic therapy (dual antiplatelet therapy) is used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alteplase: This is a thrombolytic agent used to dissolve clots but is considered when PCI is not available or will be delayed.

 

Option B. Streptokinase: Another thrombolytic agent, similar to alteplase, used when PCI is not an option.

 

Option D. Dual Antiplatelet therapy: This is an essential part of the initial management of STEMI, involving a combination of aspirin and a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor (like clopidogrel, ticagrelor, or prasugrel). However, it is not the definitive treatment compared to PCI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary angioplasty (PCI) is the best treatment for patients presenting with STEMI, especially when it can be performed within the recommended time frame, as it effectively restores blood flow to the affected myocardium. ​

questions.text: Identify the maneuver being performed in the given image? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Head tilt, chin lift

 

The maneuver performed in the given image is that of a head-tilt chin-lift. It is an important technique in emergency airway management to open up the airway.

 

  • Tilt the patient’s head back by pushing down on the forehead.
  • Place the tips of your index and middle fingers under the chin and pull up on the mandible (not on the soft tissues). This lifts the tongue away from the posterior pharynx and improves airway patency.

 

There is no absolute contraindication to it but Suspected cervical injury is a relative contraindication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Jaw thrust: Lift the mandible upward with your fingers, at least until the lower incisors are higher than the upper incisors. This maneuver lifts the tongue along with the mandible, thus relieving upper airway obstruction.

 

 

Option D. Manual inline stabilization: is a neck immobilisation technique in a natural position achieved by using the fingers and palms of both hands to stabilize the patient's occiput and mastoid processes to gently counteract the forces of airway intervention

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The head-tilt chin-lift maneuver is a key technique for opening the airway in emergency situations, especially when cervical spine injury is not suspected.

questions.text: Enzyme deficient in pompe’s disease is: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alpha 1, 4 glucosidase

 

  • Pompe's disease is caused by a deficiency of alpha-1,4-glucosidase (also known as acid maltase), an enzyme involved in the breakdown of glycogen. Pompe's disease is a lysosomal storage disorder characterized by the accumulation of glycogen in various tissues, particularly in muscles.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Glucose 6 phosphatase: This is not the correct enzyme. Glucose 6 phosphatase deficiency is associated with von Gierke's disease, a glycogen storage disorder. It primarily affects the liver and kidney.

 

Option C. Muscle phosphorylase: Muscle phosphorylase is associated with McArdle's disease, a glycogen storage disorder affecting skeletal muscles. It is not the enzyme deficient in Pompe's disease.

 

Option D. Phosphofructokinase: Phosphofructokinase is associated with Tarui's disease, another glycogen storage disorder. It is not the enzyme deficient in Pompe's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the enzymatic basis of Pompe's disease, recognizing that it is caused by a deficiency of alpha-1,4-glucosidase (acid maltase). Be aware of the clinical manifestations and biochemical abnormalities associated with Pompe's disease, which is characterized by the accumulation of glycogen in various tissues, particularly in muscles.

questions.text: Which appendicular carcinoma is most commonly associated with pseudomyxoma peritoneii? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mucinous adenocarcinoma 

 

Pseudomyxoma peritonei is a rare condition characterized by the presence of mucinous ascites due to the dissemination of mucus-producing cells within the peritoneal cavity.

 

This is a type of cancer that arises from cells that produce mucus, commonly from the appendix. It is the most common cause of pseudomyxoma peritonei, as these malignant cells can spread throughout the peritoneal cavity and secrete mucin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucinous cystadenoma: This is a benign ovarian tumor that can produce mucus, but it is less commonly associated with pseudomyxoma peritonei compared to its malignant counterparts.

 

Option C. Carcinoid tumor: Carcinoid tumors are neuroendocrine tumors that can occur in the appendix. While they can spread, they are not typically associated with the production of abundant mucin that characterizes pseudomyxoma peritonei.

 

Option D. Serous cystadenoma: This is a benign tumor that can occur in the ovaries and produce a watery serous fluid, not the mucinous ascites seen in pseudomyxoma peritonei.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Mucinous adenocarcinoma, particularly of the appendix, is the most common appendicular carcinoma associated with pseudomyxoma peritonei, characterized by the accumulation of mucinous material in the peritoneal cavity.

questions.text: Which of the following is the predominant pathogen to infect the renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytomegalovirus

 

The predominant pathogen to infect the renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation is cytomegalovirus (CMV).

 

The most common CMV presentation in kidney transplant patients is fever, leukopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, myalgia, and arthralgia.

 

JC virus, BK virus, and Epstein-Barr virus also have the propensity to cause infections during this period, but in lesser frequencies than CMV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. JC Virus: Known for causing progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), especially in patients with severe immunodeficiency, but it is less common than CMV in affecting renal transplant patients in the early months post-transplant.

 

Option C. BK Virus: This virus can affect renal transplant recipients by causing BK virus-associated nephropathy, which can lead to graft dysfunction and loss. However, its peak incidence typically occurs slightly later than CMV.

 

Option D. Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV): While EBV can cause post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder (PTLD), it is not as commonly the predominant pathogen in the early post-transplant period compared to CMV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing and managing CMV infection in the early months following renal transplantation is crucial due to its potential to cause significant morbidity and impact on graft survival. Monitoring for CMV activity and initiating pre-emptive or therapeutic antiviral treatment as indicated is key to improving transplant outcomes.

questions.text: What is the repair mechanism associated with CRISPR-Cas9? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Non-homologous end joining

 

NHEJ is the primary repair mechanism associated with CRISPR-Cas9. When CRISPR-Cas9 induces double-strand breaks in DNA, NHEJ rejoins the broken DNA ends, often introducing insertions or deletions (indels) at the repair site. This can result in gene knockout or disruption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Base excision repair (BER): BER is a DNA repair mechanism that corrects damaged or mismatched bases in the DNA. It primarily deals with single-base changes and small DNA lesions. CRISPR-Cas9, on the other hand, creates double-strand breaks, so BER is not directly involved in repairing these breaks.

 

Option B. Nucleotide excision repair (NER): NER is another DNA repair mechanism that mainly deals with the removal of larger DNA lesions, such as those caused by UV radiation. It is not the primary repair mechanism associated with CRISPR-Cas9-induced double-strand breaks.

 

Option D. Mismatch repair (MMR): MMR is a repair mechanism that corrects errors in DNA replication, specifically base-pair mismatches and small insertion-deletion loops. It is not the primary mechanism involved in repairing double-strand breaks created by CRISPR-Cas9.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary repair mechanism associated with CRISPR-Cas9 is non-homologous end joining (NHEJ), which repairs double-strand breaks by ligating the broken DNA ends, potentially causing insertions or deletions that disrupt the target gene.

questions.text: Which of the following is not involved in urethritis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) H.ducreyi

 

Haemophilus ducreyi is the causative agent of chancroid (Soft Chancre), a sexually transmitted infection characterized by painful genital ulcers and lymphadenopathy, not urethritis. Urethritis involves inflammation of the urethra, typically presenting with symptoms such as dysuria and discharge. H. ducreyi specifically causes ulcerative lesions rather than the typical inflammation and discharge associated with urethritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichomonas: While primarily known for causing trichomoniasis (a vaginitis), Trichomonas can occasionally cause urethritis, particularly in women.

 

Option B. Chlamydia: The most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis, particularly among sexually transmitted bacterial infections.

 

Option C. Gonococcus (Neisseria gonorrhoeae): A well-known cause of gonococcal urethritis, presenting typically with a more severe and purulent discharge compared to NGU.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urethritis is classified into two types:

 

  1. Gonococcal urethritis - caused by Neisseria gonorrhea.
  2. Non-gonococcal urethritis - caused by:
    • Chlamydia trachomatis (most common)
    • Ureaplasma urealyticum
    • Adenovirus
    • Haemophilus vaginalis
    • Mycoplasma genitalium
    • Tricomonas vaginalis (rare)
    • Herpes simplex virus (rare)

questions.text: What is the most common cause of agranulocytosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Drug toxicity

 

Drug toxicity is the most common cause of agranulocytosis. Agranulocytosis is a condition in which there is a severe decrease in the number of white blood cells called granulocytes, which are responsible for fighting bacterial infections. Certain medications, such as chemotherapy drugs, antibiotics, antipsychotics, and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), can cause agranulocytosis as a side effect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Marrow infiltration: While it can cause agranulocytosis, it is less common than drug-induced cases.

 

Option B. Autoimmune: Can lead to agranulocytosis through immune-mediated destruction of neutrophils but is also less frequent than drug toxicity.

 

Option D. Radiation exposure: Can suppress bone marrow but typically in the context of higher and prolonged exposures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Causes of agranulocytosis include:

 

  • Inadequate or ineffective granulopoiesis
  • Suppression of hematopoietic stem cells - aplastic anemia, infiltrative marrow disorders
  • Suppression of committed granulocytic precursors
  • Ineffective hematopoiesis - megaloblastic anemia, myelodysplastic syndromes
  • Congenital conditions - Kostmann syndrome
  • Increased destruction or sequestration of neutrophils -
  • Immunological injury to neutrophils - idiopathic, systemic lupus erythematosus, drug exposure
  • Increased peripheral utilization - bacterial, fungal, or rickettsial infections
  • Splenomegaly

choices.text: Decrease in partial pressure of oxygen
Both option a and b are correct
None of the above is correct

questions.text: What is the reason behind developing breathing difficulty at high altitudes? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Decrease in partial pressure of oxygen

 

  • The primary reason for breathing difficulty at high altitudes is the decrease in the partial pressure of oxygen (PO2). At higher elevations, atmospheric pressure is lower, which in turn decreases the PO2. This reduction leads to a lower oxygen saturation of hemoglobin in the blood, a condition known as hypoxia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decrease in hemoglobin concentration: Incorrect in this context. Hemoglobin concentration does not necessarily decrease at high altitudes initially; in fact, over time, the body may increase hemoglobin production as an adaptive response to chronic hypoxia.

 

Option C. Both option A and B are correct: Incorrect because only the decrease in PO2 is relevant in the immediate context of acute altitude exposure. Changes in hemoglobin concentration are more of a long-term adaptation.

 

Option D. None of the above is correct: Incorrect as option B accurately describes the reason for breathing difficulty at high altitudes.

 

Physiological Adaptations at High Altitudes

 

  1. Increased Ventilation: The body compensates for lower oxygen availability by increasing respiratory rate and depth (hyperventilation) to enhance oxygen uptake.
  2. Increased Red Blood Cell Production: With prolonged exposure to high altitudes, the body increases erythropoietin production, which stimulates the production of red blood cells, increasing the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood.
  3. Increased Hemoglobin Affinity for Oxygen: There may be physiological changes leading to an increase in hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen, helping it to capture more oxygen under conditions of reduced PO2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Breathing difficulty at high altitudes is primarily caused by a decrease in the partial pressure of oxygen due to reduced atmospheric pressure, leading to insufficient oxygen availability and hypoxia. This challenges the body to adapt through various physiological mechanisms to maintain adequate oxygen delivery to tissues.

questions.text:
Arrange in sequence the structures involved in the direct pathway: (INICET NOV 2022)

 

1. Striatum

2. Globus pallidus

3. Substantia nigra

4. Thalamus

5. Cortex
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 5,1,2,3,4

 

Explanation:

 

The correct sequence is as follows:

 

5. Cortex - provides the initial input to the basal ganglia.

 

1. Striatum - receives input from the cortex and is the first structure in the basal ganglia circuitry.

 

2. Globus pallidus - receives inhibitory input from the striatum and projects to the thalamus.

 

3. Substantia nigra - provides dopaminergic input to the striatum.

 

4. Thalamus - receives excitatory input from the globus pallidus and projects back to the cortex to complete the loop.

 

The basal ganglia needs the input from the cortex in order to act. The first and last component of the pathway is always the cerebral cortex. 


The complete pathway is Cortex/ Thalamus/ brain stem to stratum, then to globus pallidus & substantia nigra then to thalamus and then back to cortex.


Hence out of the available options 5,1,2,3,4 is the best suitable.

 

 

 

The putamen is located laterally and the internal capsule is located medially to the pallidum. The striatum and subthalamic nuclei send fibres to it. It is the primary basal ganglia output to the thalamus and superior colliculus. Each cerebral peduncle of the midbrain located deep to the crus cerebri contains the substantia nigra. Dopamine levels in the substantia nigra and striata are reduced in Parkinson's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct order of structures in the direct pathway of the basal ganglia starts with the cortex and follows through the striatum, globus pallidus, substantia nigra, and ends at the thalamus. This pathway is fundamental in processing motor signals, which is particularly relevant in understanding disorders like Parkinson’s disease.

questions.text: Which contrast is used in PET scan? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) FDG

 

Positron Emission Tomography (PET) is an imaging technique used primarily in oncology, cardiology, and neurology. The contrast agent used in PET scans is 18F-FDG (fluorodeoxyglucose). FDG (a ligand) is a radiopharmaceutical composed of glucose molecules labeled with the positron-emitting isotope fluorine-18.

 

When injected into the body, FDG mimics glucose and is taken up by cells with high glucose metabolism, such as cancer cells. The Warburg effect, a phenomenon where cancer cells preferentially consume glucose for energy, makes FDG particularly useful in identifying tumors. The positrons emitted by fluorine-18 interact with electrons in the body, producing gamma rays that are detected by the PET scanner to create detailed images of metabolic activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iohexol: Iohexol is an iodinated contrast agent typically used in CT (Computed Tomography) scans, not PET scans. It does not emit positrons and is not used to highlight areas of high metabolic activity.

 

Option B. Calcium: Calcium is not used as a contrast agent in PET scans. While calcium can be a component of certain contrast agents used in other types of imaging like fluoroscopy, it has no role in PET imaging.

 

Option C. Gadolinium: Gadolinium is a contrast agent used in MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging). It helps enhance the contrast of images in MRI but does not work with the PET scanning process, which relies on positron emission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The contrast agent used in PET scans is 18F-FDG (fluorodeoxyglucose), which highlights areas of increased glucose metabolism, such as cancer cells.

questions.text: Definitive Investigation for a patient of dengue who presented with features of Dengue hemorrhagic syndrome since last 5 days is: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) RT-PCR

 

RT-PCR (Reverse Transcription Polymerase Chain Reaction) is the most definitive investigation for diagnosing dengue, particularly in the first five days of illness. RT-PCR is highly sensitive and specific, capable of detecting the viral RNA present in the blood.

 

Although NS1 antigen detection is another option for early diagnosis, RT-PCR provides more reliable results, especially around the 3rd day of illness.

 

Studies indicate that within the first five days, RT-PCR is superior to the NS1 antigen test in detecting dengue infection. After five days, when the viral RNA levels decrease, ELISA IgM becomes a more suitable test as it detects the presence of antibodies developed against the virus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NS-1 antigen: The NS1 antigen test is useful in the early diagnosis of dengue, typically within the first few days of illness. However, it is most effective around the 2nd day of illness and is less reliable compared to RT-PCR by the 5th day.

 

Option C. Viral culture: Viral culture is not typically used in clinical settings for the diagnosis of dengue because it is time-consuming, requires specialized facilities, and is less practical for rapid diagnosis.

 

Option D. ELISA IgM: ELISA IgM is a serological test that detects antibodies produced in response to dengue infection. It becomes more effective after 5 days of illness, when the immune response is more developed, making it unsuitable for diagnosis within the first five days.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient presenting with dengue symptoms within the first five days, RT-PCR is the definitive diagnostic test due to its high sensitivity and ability to detect viral RNA during this critical period.

choices.text: Regardless of ejection fraction and the type of heart failure, the 5-year mortality rate is around 50%.
Non-cardiovascular death is more in HFrEF as compared to HFpEF.
ACEi cause cough in 15% and angioedema in 1%.
AF is common in the elderly and is the cause of stroke in a quarter of stroke cases.

questions.text: All are true regarding heart failure except: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Non-cardiovascular death is more in HFrEF as compared to HFpEF.

 

Non-cardiovascular death refers to mortality due to causes other than cardiovascular diseases, such as infections, accidents, or malignancies.

 

The majority of deaths in HFrEF (Heart Failure with reduced Ejection Fraction) are due to cardiovascular causes (85%), and only 15% are due to non-cardiovascular causes.

 

In contrast, in HFpEF (Heart Failure with preserved Ejection Fraction), 60% of deaths are cardiovascular, and 40% are non-cardiovascular.

 

Therefore, non-cardiovascular death is actually more prevalent in HFpEF patients compared to HFrEF patients, making option B incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Regardless of ejection fraction and the type of heart failure, the 5-year mortality rate is around 50%: This statement is correct. Both HFpEF and HFrEF patients have similar 5-year mortality rates, approximately 50%. This indicates that having a preserved ejection fraction does not necessarily correlate with a better long-term survival rate compared to reduced ejection fraction.

 

Option C. ACEi cause cough in 15% and angioedema in 1%: This statement is correct. Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme inhibitors (ACEi) are known to cause a persistent cough in about 15% of patients and angioedema, a more serious but less common side effect, in approximately 1% of patients.

 

Option D. AF is common in the elderly and is the cause of stroke in a quarter of stroke cases: This statement is correct. Atrial Fibrillation (AF) is indeed common among elderly patients and is a significant cause of cardioembolic strokes, accounting for about 25% of such cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-cardiovascular deaths are more common in HFpEF patients compared to HFrEF patients.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy will have ____ permanent and ____ temporary teeth?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 20, 4

 

Explanation:

 

Mixed dentition is a period when both temporary (primary) and permanent teeth are present in the oral cavity. This phase typically occurs between the ages of 6 to 11 years.

 

Key points to remember about mixed dentition:

 

1. Age Range: The mixed dentition period spans from 6 to 11 years.

 

2. Total Number of Teeth: During mixed dentition, the total number of teeth (temporary plus permanent) is consistently 24.

 

3. Calculation of Permanent Teeth: The number of permanent teeth can be calculated using the formula:

 

Permanent Teeth=(Age−5)×4

 

For a 10-year-old child:

 

Permanent Teeth=(10−5)×4=20

 

Hence, the number of permanent teeth is 20.

 

4. Calculation of Temporary Teeth: The number of temporary teeth can be determined by subtracting the number of permanent teeth from the total number of teeth:

 

Temporary Teeth=24−Permanent Teeth

 

Therefore:

 

Temporary Teeth=24−20=4

 

Thus, a 10-year-old boy will have 20 permanent teeth and 4 temporary teeth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During the mixed dentition period (6-11 years), a 10-year-old typically has 20 permanent teeth and 4 temporary teeth. Use the formula (Age−5)×4  to determine the number of permanent teeth.

 

Number if teeth with age -

choices.text: A-1 B-2 C-3
A-2 B-1 C-3
A-3 B-2 C-1
A-1 B-3 C-2

questions.text: Match the following dilution of adrenaline and its use? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A-2 B-1 C-3

 

Dilutions of adrenaline (epinephrine) with their typical uses:

 

  1. 1:1000 dilution of adrenaline is more concentrated and is commonly used in the treatment of Anaphylaxis. It is administered intramuscularly in emergency situations for its rapid vasoconstrictive and bronchodilating effects.
  2. 1:10000 dilution is less concentrated and is typically used in the management of Cardiac Arrest. It's administered intravenously.
  3. 1:100000 dilution is used as an additive in Local Anesthesia. The vasoconstrictive properties of adrenaline help to prolong the action of the local anesthetic and reduce bleeding in the surgical field.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Mixed cellar type
Nodular sclerosis
Lymphocyte predominant
Classical Hodgkin Lymphoma

questions.text: L & H type Reed-Sternberg (RS) cell is seen in: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lymphocyte predominant

 

In lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma, L and H type Reed-Sternberg cells are seen.

 

It is distinguished by the presence of lymphohistiocytic (L&H) variant RS cells, also known as LP cells, with a delicate multilobed, puffy nucleus that resembles popped corn (popcorn cell). Other reactive cells, such as eosinophils, are scarce or absent, and RS cells are uncommon.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Mixed cell type, B. Nodular sclerosis and D. Classical Hodgkin Lymphoma: These categories of Hodgkin lymphoma typically feature classical RS cells which express CD15 and CD30 and do not have the popcorn-like appearance of the L&H variant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

L & H type Reed-Sternberg cells, displaying a popcorn-like appearance and expressing B-cell markers, are a hallmark of lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma.

choices.text: Rapid release of calcium by osteocytes
Rapid release of calcium by osteoclasts
Rapid release of calcium from bones and increased calcium reabsorption in kidneys
Increase calcium reabsorption in kidneys

questions.text: PTH increases Calcium in blood. This is due to:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rapid release of calcium from bones and increased calcium reabsorption in kidneys:

 

Parathyroid hormone (PTH) primarily acts to increase the concentration of calcium in the blood. It achieves this through several mechanisms:

  1. Stimulation of osteoclasts to resorb bone, leading to the release of calcium from the bones.
  2. Increased absorption of calcium in the intestines.
  3. Stimulation of the kidneys to reabsorb more calcium, reducing its excretion in the urine.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Rapid release of calcium by osteocytes: Osteocytes are embedded in the bone matrix and are not directly involved in the rapid release of calcium. Osteoclasts, on the other hand, are responsible for bone resorption.

 

Option B. Rapid release of calcium by osteoclasts: Osteoclasts are indeed involved in the rapid release of calcium from bones. However, the complete action of PTH includes not only osteoclast activity but also increased calcium reabsorption in the kidneys.

 

Option D. Increase calcium reabsorption in kidneys: While PTH does stimulate increased calcium reabsorption in the kidneys, the complete action also involves the rapid release of calcium from bones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective here is to understand the role of parathyroid hormone (PTH) in regulating calcium levels in the blood and the mechanisms by which it accomplishes this task.

 

  • Role of PTH in Calcium Regulation: PTH is a hormone produced by the parathyroid glands, which are small glands located in the neck. Its primary function is to regulate calcium homeostasis in the body, ensuring that blood calcium levels remain within a narrow and critical range.
  • Increase in Blood Calcium: PTH increases blood calcium levels by stimulating various physiological processes:
    • Stimulation of Osteoclasts: PTH activates osteoclasts, specialized bone cells responsible for breaking down bone tissue. This results in the release of calcium from the bones into the bloodstream.
    • Enhanced Calcium Reabsorption: PTH enhances the reabsorption of calcium by the kidneys. This means that less calcium is excreted in urine, conserving it for use in the body.
    • Activation of Vitamin D: PTH indirectly stimulates the production of active vitamin D (calcitriol) in the kidneys. Calcitriol helps increase calcium absorption from the digestive tract, further contributing to higher blood calcium levels.
  • Negative Feedback Loop: The regulation of PTH secretion is tightly controlled by a negative feedback loop. When blood calcium levels drop below the normal range, the parathyroid glands release PTH, which acts to raise calcium levels. Once calcium levels return to normal, PTH secretion decreases, preventing excess calcium in the blood.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents to the ER with a history of trauma two weeks back with confusion and ataxia. CT scan reveals the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subdural haemorrhage

 

  • The given clinical scenario and the plain CT scan is suggestive of subdural hematoma (SDH).
  • Subdural hematomas typically occur due to the rupture of bridging veins, which can be associated with mild trauma, cerebral atrophy, elderly age, or chronic alcohol overuse.
  •  The presentation of symptoms like confusion and ataxia two weeks after trauma is characteristic of a chronic subdural hematoma.

 

Subdural Hematoma (SDH)

 

  • Pathology: Rupture of bridging veins.
  • Etiology: Can be acute (traumatic) or chronic (associated with mild trauma, cerebral atrophy, elderly age, chronic alcohol overuse). Also seen in shaken babies.
  • Clinical Features: Typically presents without a lucid interval; altered consciousness from the onset. Features of raised intracranial tension and neurological deficits may be present.
  • CT Findings: Crescent-shaped hemorrhage that crosses suture lines.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extradural Hemorrhage

 

  • Pathology: Rupture of the middle meningeal artery (branch of the maxillary artery), often secondary to a skull fracture involving the pterion.
  • Clinical Features: Often includes a lucid interval (period of normalcy between two periods of unconsciousness).
  • CT Findings: Biconvex (lentiform), hyperdense blood collection that does not cross suture lines.

 

Option C. Intra-parenchymal Hemorrhage

 

  • Pathology: Most commonly caused by systemic hypertension.
  • Location: Most often occurs in the putamen/globus pallidus of the basal ganglia (lenticulostriate vessels).
  • CT Findings: Intra-parenchymal bleed.

 

Option D. Subarachnoid Hemorrhage

 

  • Pathology: Bleeding due to trauma or rupture of an aneurysm (such as a saccular aneurysm).
  • Clinical Features: Patients complain of the “worst headache of my life.” Bloody or yellow lumbar puncture. Vasospasm can occur, nimodipine is used to prevent/reduce it.
  • CT Findings: Intraventricular and subarachnoid space hyperdensities represent acute hemorrhages.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Subdural hematoma typically results from the rupture of bridging veins and presents without a lucid interval.
  •  CT scans of subdural hematoma show a crescent-shaped hemorrhage that crosses suture lines.

questions.text: A particular community population has been consuming Maize as a staple diet for years. The vitamin deficiency most likely to be seen in this population is: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Niacin

 

Maize, commonly consumed as a staple food in many communities, is deficient in the amino acid tryptophan, which is crucial for the synthesis of niacin (Vitamin B3) in the body. Niacin can be synthesized endogenously from tryptophan at a conversion rate of 60 mg of tryptophan to 1 mg of niacin. However, when maize is a primary dietary component, the body lacks sufficient tryptophan, leading to niacin deficiency.

 

Moreover, maize is high in leucine, an amino acid that inhibits the conversion of tryptophan to niacin via the kynurenine pathway. This combination of low tryptophan and high leucine content makes niacin deficiency prevalent in populations consuming maize as a staple diet, resulting in pellagra.

 

Pellagra is characterized by the “4 Ds”: Diarrhea, Dermatitis, Dementia, and Death if untreated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine: Thiamine deficiency is typically associated with polished rice consumption, not maize. It leads to conditions like beriberi.

 

Option B. Riboflavin: Riboflavin deficiency, though possible, is not specifically linked to maize consumption. It typically results from general dietary insufficiency of various foods, not specific to maize.

 

Option D. Cyanocobalamin: Cyanocobalamin (Vitamin B12) deficiency is generally seen in populations with low intake of animal products and is not related to maize consumption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maize as a staple diet leads to niacin deficiency due to its low tryptophan and high leucine content, resulting in pellagra.

 

Note – Leucine is known as pellagrogenic aminoacid in India

questions.text: A researcher is studying the spread of a new viral illness. He wants to determine the probability that a susceptible person will contract the disease after close contact with an infected person. Which measure best describes this probability? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Secondary attack rate

 

The secondary attack rate (SAR) measures the probability that a susceptible individual will contract the disease after coming into close contact with an infected individual. It is a useful measure for gauging the infectious potential of an agent within a population.

 

Infectivity is known by calculating the secondary attack rates.


SAR = (Total no. of secondary cases * 100) / (Total susceptible population-primary cases)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serial interval is the average time difference between the primary and secondary case, which is similar to the median incubation period

 

Option C. Incubation period: Entry of organism in the human body till the first sign / symptom is produced.

 

Option D. The Case fatality rate = (Number of deaths due to a disease / number of cases of that particular disease) * 100

 

Case fatality rate typically is used as a measure of disease severity and is often used for prognosis. Always expressed in %. CFR of Rabies is 100%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The secondary attack rate (SAR) is a critical measure for assessing the infectious potential of a disease, indicating the likelihood that a disease will spread among susceptible individuals after exposure to an infected person.

questions.text: A 4-week-old child was brought to the emergency with recurrent episodes of non-bilious vomiting. He was dehydrated. What should be corrected before performing surgical treatment in this baby? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypokalemia

 

The child presents with recurrent non-bilious vomiting, which is a classic sign of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS). IHPS is a condition in infants causing severe vomiting due to the thickening of the pylorus muscle, leading to obstruction.

 

Patients with IHPS often develop a specific electrolyte imbalance characterized by hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis. The vomiting leads to a loss of gastric acid (hydrochloric acid), resulting in low chloride levels and secondary metabolic alkalosis. This condition also results in potassium loss, leading to hypokalemia.

 

Before performing surgical treatment (such as a pyloromyotomy, often referenced in this context as the Ramstedt procedure), it is crucial to correct the electrolyte imbalance to stabilize the patient. The primary focus is on correcting hypokalemia because potassium is essential for normal cellular function and cardiac rhythm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyperkalemia: This condition involves high potassium levels, which is not typically seen in patients with IHPS. Instead, these patients usually have low potassium levels due to vomiting.

 

Option C. Hyponatremia: While hyponatremia (low sodium levels) can occur, it is generally not as significant or immediately life-threatening as hypokalemia in the context of IHPS.

 

Option D. Hypernatremia: High sodium levels are not characteristic of IHPS. The vomiting associated with IHPS more commonly leads to losses of electrolytes like potassium and chloride, not an increase in sodium levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS) is often associated with hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis. Correction of hypokalemia is essential before surgical intervention.

questions.text: Calculate the percentage of burns in a patient that presented to the  emergency with flame burn injury covering the entire  chest and abdomen, the entire right upper limb and full circumference of the  right thigh.(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 36

 

To calculate the percentage of body surface area affected by burns, the Rule of Nines is often used in adults. This method divides the body into sections that represent 9% (or multiples thereof) of the body surface area.

 

As per the case scenario given :

 

  • Chest and abdomen: 18%
  • Right upper limb: 9%
  • Right thigh: 9%

 

Total = 18% (chest and abdomen) + 9% (right upper limb) + 9% (right thigh) = 36%

 

Educational Objective:

 

This calculation as per the case scenario and Wallace rule of 9 results in a total burned body surface area of 36%, which corresponds to option B.

 

Rule of Nine

choices.text: Bladder training, with reward for delaying micturition during daytime
Bell and pad based classical conditioning

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presented with complaints of bed-wetting almost twice a week for the past 1 year. A detailed investigation was done to rule out the organic cause. What should be the treatment plan for this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bell and pad based classical conditioning

 

This is a first-line behavioral treatment for primary nocturnal enuresis. It involves an alarm that sounds when wetness is detected, conditioning the child to awaken and use the toilet.

 

Other Options:

 

The child described seems to have primary nocturnal enuresis, which is common in children and often has no organic cause:

 

Option A. Pharmacotherapy with imipramine: This is an option, but it's usually reserved for cases that don't respond to first-line treatments because of potential side effects.

 

Option B. Psychodynamic psychotherapy: Not typically used as a first-line treatment for nocturnal enuresis.

 

Option C. Bladder training: This focuses on delaying micturition during daytime, which is beneficial but not considered as the treatment of choice

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Sleep related enuresis is defined as voiding of urine at inappropriate places. It is nocturnal in around 80% of cases. The most common cause of bed wetting are psychosocial such as sibling rivalry. The treatment of choice is bed alarms. Drug of choice is desmopressin. Another medication which can be used is imipramine.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 169.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the given image? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Unicornuate uterus

 

The given image shows the HSG of a Unicornuate uterus. The endometrial cavity forms a fusiform (banana type) shape, tapering at the apex and draining into a single fallopian tube. The uterus is generally shifted off the midline.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterus didelphys is a type of Müllerian duct anomaly where there is a complete duplication of uterine horns as well as duplication of the cervix, with no communication between them.

 

 

Option B. Bicornuate uterus is due to incomplete fusion of the mullerian ducts and is characterized by the presence of a cleft in the external contour of the uterine fundus.

 

 

Option C. Septate uterus is the result of partial or complete failure of resorption of the uterovaginal septum after fusion of the paramesonephric ducts.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Unicornuate uterus is identified on HSG by a fusiform shape and a single fallopian tube connection, often displaced from the midline, indicating unilateral Müllerian duct development.

questions.text: A person presents in ENT OPD having nasal blockage with crusts, foul-smelling discharge, and hyposmia. On examination, nose is hard, and biopsy reveals following histopathological findings. What is the likely cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation of nasal blockage, crusts, foul-smelling discharge, and hyposmia, along with the finding of a hard nose and the specific histopathological findings in the biopsy (such as Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies), are indicative of rhinoscleroma caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous condition that leads to the hardening of the nasal tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rhinosporidium seeberi: This condition would show sporangia containing endospores on histopathology, which is not seen in this case.

 

 

Option B. Klebsiella ozaenae: Typically causes atrophic rhinitis characterized by foul-smelling discharge and crusting, but it does not cause a hard nose or the specific histopathological findings seen here.

 

 

Option D. Autoimmunity: Autoimmune conditions can cause nasal symptoms but are not characterized by the specific histopathological findings of Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhinoscleroma, caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, presents with a hard nose, nasal blockage, crusting, foul-smelling discharge, and specific histopathological findings such as Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies.

questions.text: The Para-sagittal section of the abdomen is given below. What is the superior border of the structure marked A?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Caudate lobe of liver

 

Explanation:

 

Epiploic foramen is the structure indicated in the provided image. The caudate lobe of the liver forms the superior boundary of the epiploic foramen, also known as the foramen of Winslow.

 

Epiploic foramen is a vertical slit of about 3 cm behind the free right border of the lesser omentum. It connects the lesser sac to the greater sac. The pearl summarizes the various relations of the foramen.

 

 

The caudate lobe is a small lobe of the liver situated on the posterior aspect, between the sulcus for the vena cava on the right and the fissure for the ligamentum venosum on the left. The caudate lobe forms the superior border of the epiploic foramen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Duodenum: The duodenum is the first part of the small intestine immediately beyond the stomach. While the duodenum is closely related to the epiploic foramen, specifically the posterior surface of its first part, it does not form the superior border. Instead, it comprises the posterior boundary.

 

Option C. Lesser omentum: The lesser omentum is a double layer of peritoneum that extends from the liver to the lesser curvature of the stomach and the start of the duodenum. The free edge of the lesser omentum contains the bile duct, hepatic artery, and portal vein, forming the anterior border of the epiploic foramen.

 

Option D. Inferior vena cava: The inferior vena cava (IVC) is a large vein that carries deoxygenated blood from the lower and middle body into the right atrium of the heart. It is located posteriorly to the epiploic foramen but does not form the superior border. It creates the posterior boundary, similar to the duodenum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The epiploic foramen, also known as the foramen of Winslow, is a key anatomical passage within the abdominal cavity that connects the greater sac to the lesser sac.

 

The caudate lobe of the liver forms the superior border of this foramen.

questions.text: Most common joint involved in septic arthritis is:  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Knee

 

SEPTIC (PYOGENIC) ARTHRITIS

 

  • Refers to Infection of Joint.
  • Septic arthritis word is a misnomer as initially, there is only infection of joint and if not treated early then, Arthritis develops. Thus, all sepsis of joints do not cause arthritis, only inadequately treated ones do.
  • Etiology and pathology:
    • Hematogenous route of infection is most common in all age groups
    • Most common organism: Staphylococcus aureus.
       
  • Diagnosis:
    • X-rays are usually normal or may indicate soft tissue swelling.
    • MRI may show effusion, synovitis or cartilage destruction.
    • Aspiration of joint fluid helps to confirm the diagnosis by culture and also helps to differentiate from transient synovitis.
    • Order of investigations done: X-ray followed by MRI, then Aspiration.
    • Culture of the aspirate is the gold standard for diagnosis.
       
  • Septic arthritis with negative cultures: Diagnostic Criterion (Morrey and associates criterion) – 5 out of 6 must be present
    1. > 38.3°C temperature
    2. Swelling of suspected joint
    3. Pain in joint that increases with movement
    4. Systemic symptoms
    5. No other pathologic process
    6. Satisfactory response to antibiotics therapy
       
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Absent movements of a joint after ruling out trauma in pediatric population is septic arthritis until proven otherwise.
    • Knee: Most commonly affected joint; position is flexion
    • Hip: Position is flexion, abduction and external rotation.
       
  • Treatment:
    • Arthrotomy (opening the joint capsule), surgical drainage (decompression), synovectomy and antibiotics (2 weeks IV and 4 weeks oral).
    • Non-operative treatment is not considered as cartilage destruction occurs very rapidly and can cause permanent joint destruction.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Hip. Infections that can affect the hip are primarily either an infection of the bone i.e., osteomyelitis, or an infection of the joint i.e., septic arthritis. 

 

Option C. Shoulder. Infection of the shoulder joint is rare. It may occur after total shoulder replacement. The most common bacteria responsible for the infection are Staphylococcus aureus, Staphylococcus epidermidis, and Propionibacterium acnes.

 

Option D. Elbow. Elbow joint infection may occur due to infected or septic arthritis, septic joint, infection after elbow surgery or after elbow replacement, bursal infection, soft tissue infection or cellulitis. 

 

Educational objective:

 

The most common joint involved in septic arthritis is the knee joint, followed by the hip joint.

choices.text: Pedicled TRAM based on superior epigastric artery
Free TRAM based on inferior epigastric artery
DIEP based on deep inferior epigastric artery

questions.text: Identify the false statement about the flaps used in breast reconstruction?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) DIEP is a myocutaneous flap

 

Explanation:

 

The Deep Inferior Epigastric Perforator (DIEP) flap is a type of breast reconstruction flap that is derived from the deep inferior epigastric artery. The DIEP flap is a muscle-sparing flap, meaning it involves only the removal of skin, fat, and blood vessels (perforators), without taking any of the rectus abdominis muscle. This reduces the risk of post-operative abdominal weakness and complications, unlike the Transverse Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous (TRAM) flap, which includes muscle. Therefore, it is incorrect to refer to the DIEP flap as a myocutaneous flap because it does not include muscle.

 

DIEP is a myocutaneous flap: This statement is false. A myocutaneous flap includes muscle tissue, whereas the DIEP flap spares the rectus abdominis muscle, utilizing only the skin, fat, and perforator vessels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pedicled TRAM based on superior epigastric artery: The pedicled TRAM flap stands for Transverse Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous flap. It relies on the superior epigastric artery for blood supply, which remains attached (pedicled) to its original source. The flap, including the rectus muscle, is tunneled under the skin to the chest to reconstruct the breast. This statement is accurate.

 

Option B. Free TRAM based on inferior epigastric artery: The free TRAM flap involves the removal of a section of the abdominal tissue, including the rectus muscle, along with the inferior epigastric arteries. This flap is transplanted to the chest and connected to the chest's blood vessels using microsurgical techniques. This flap utilizes both the superior and inferior epigastric arteries. This statement is accurate.

 

Option C. DIEP based on deep inferior epigastric artery: The DIEP flap is similar to the free TRAM flap but does not involve the removal of the rectus muscle. Instead, it uses only the skin, fat, and perforator blood vessels based on the deep inferior epigastric artery. This design spares the abdominal muscles, reducing post-operative complications. This statement is accurate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The DIEP flap is a muscle-sparing flap used in breast reconstruction, involving the skin, fat, and blood vessels without including muscle tissue, which differentiates it from a myocutaneous flap like the TRAM flap.

questions.text: A patient presented with hypertension, increased heart rate, and sweating. He sees red halos after hearing the radio. Which substance's abuse can cause this? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) LSD

 

The patient's symptoms include hypertension, increased heart rate, and reflex hallucinations (seeing red halos in response to auditory stimuli).

 

Reflex hallucinations occur when a stimulus in one sensory modality triggers a hallucination in another sensory modality, such as an auditory stimulus leading to a visual hallucination.

 

LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) is a hallucinogen known to cause such reflex hallucinations. Additionally, LSD can lead to sympathetic symptoms like hypertension and increased heart rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cocaine: Although cocaine can cause sympathetic symptoms such as hypertension and increased heart rate, it is less commonly associated with reflex hallucinations.

 

Option B. Alcohol: Alcohol abuse typically does not present with reflex hallucinations and the described symptoms.

 

Option C. Heroin: Heroin is an opioid that typically causes sedation and respiratory depression, not reflex hallucinations or sympathetic symptoms.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

LSD, a hallucinogen, can cause reflex hallucinations, where a stimulus in one sensory modality (e.g., auditory) produces a hallucination in another modality (e.g., visual), along with sympathetic symptoms like hypertension and increased heart rate.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a branch of the posterior division of the internal iliac artery? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Inferior gluteal artery

 

  • Origin: The inferior gluteal artery is typically a branch of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery.
  • Course & Supply: It exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen, usually below the piriformis muscle. It supplies the gluteal muscles (mainly gluteus maximus), and also gives off branches that participate in anastomoses around the hip joint.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iliolumbar Artery

 

  • Origin: This arises from the posterior division of the internal iliac artery.
  • Course & Supply: It ascends posteriorly to supply the iliacus muscle, the iliac bone, and the lumbosacral region. Its branches also participate in anastomoses with the lumbar arteries.

 

Option B. Lateral Sacral Artery

 

  • Origin: This too arises from the posterior division of the internal iliac artery.
  • Course & Supply: Generally, there are two lateral sacral arteries (superior and inferior) that descend to supply the sacrum and coccyx. They anastomose with the median sacral artery and with each other. Some branches of the lateral sacral arteries also supply the meninges of the sacral part of the spinal cord.

 

Option D. Superior Gluteal Artery

 

  • Origin: This artery arises from the posterior division of the internal iliac artery.
  • Course & Supply: It leaves the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen, usually above the piriformis muscle. It supplies the gluteal muscles and also contributes to the anastomotic network around the hip joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Branches of the anterior trunk of the internal iliac artery:

 

  1. Vaginal artery (in females)
  2. Uterine artery (in females)
  3. Inferior vesical artery (in males) or vaginal artery (in females): supplies the urinary bladder and reproductive organs.
  4. Middle rectal artery: supplies the rectum and anal canal.
  5. Internal pudendal artery: supplies the perineum, external genitalia, and the lower anal canal.
  6. Obturator artery: supplies the adductor muscles of the thigh, external genitalia, and the hip joint.
  7. Inferior gluteal artery: supplies the muscles of the gluteal region.
  8. Superior vesical artery: supplies the urinary bladder and the vas deferens.

questions.text: A bubonic outbreak has occurred within the community. What is the responsible vector for this condition? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Xenopsylla cheopis

 

Xenopsylla cheopis, commonly known as a rat flea, serves as the carrier for the bubonic plague. This particular flea species can be recognized by its distinctive conical-shaped head, along with a thorax, abdomen, and three sets of legs.


 

  • Plague is a zoonotic disease caused by Yersinia pestis.
  • The reservoir of infections is wild rodents.
  • Humans acquire the disease by the bite of an infected flea, by direct contact with the tissues of the infected animal, or by droplet infection from cases of pneumonic plague.
  • Human plague mainly presents as:

 

 

Bubonic plague- This is the most common type of disease. There is fever along with painful lymphadenitis. Within a few days, the lymph nodes in the groin, axilla, or neck enlarge and are called buboes. This is followed by the suppuration of the buboes.

 

Pneumonic plague- It develops as a complication of bubonic-septicemic plague.

 

Septicemic plague- It occurs when the infection spreads to blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Species Phlebotomus argentipes: belongs to the group of sand fly. It transmits kala azar. Other diseases transmitted by sand flies are sandfly fever and oriental sore.

 

Option C. Ixodes Tick: transmits Lyme’s disease caused by Borrelia burgdorferi.

 

Option D. Female Anopheles mosquito transmits malaria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Xenopsylla cheopis (rat flea) is the primary vector responsible for transmitting the bubonic plague, caused by Yersinia pestis. Understanding the vector and transmission routes is crucial for controlling and preventing outbreaks.

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic liver disease presents with abdominal distension, jaundice, and pruritis. Ascitic fluid analysis revealed a neutrophil count > 650 per cubic mm. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis

 

Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) is a common and serious complication in patients with chronic liver disease and ascites. It is diagnosed when the ascitic fluid neutrophil count exceeds 250 cells/mm3. In this case, the neutrophil count is significantly higher than the threshold, indicating a strong likelihood of SBP.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Chronic Liver Disease Symptoms: The patient presents with symptoms typical of chronic liver disease, including abdominal distension, jaundice, and pruritis.
  • Neutrophil Count: An ascitic fluid neutrophil count > 250 cells/mm3 is diagnostic of SBP. This patient's count of > 650 cells/mm3 strongly supports this diagnosis.
  • Management: Immediate antibiotic therapy is crucial for SBP. Standard treatment involves third-generation cephalosporins like cefotaxime or ceftriaxone. In areas with high resistance to these antibiotics, piperacillin-tazobactam used in India.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malignant Ascites: Malignant ascites is associated with peritoneal carcinomatosis or other cancers. The neutrophil count in ascitic fluid in such cases is generally lower, and the fluid is often exudative rather than the neutrophil-predominant fluid seen in SBP.

 

Option C. Tubercular Ascites: Tubercular ascites usually presents with a lymphocyte-predominant fluid rather than neutrophil-predominant. It is also associated with other findings such as a high protein content and a positive acid-fast bacilli smear.

 

Option D. Intestinal Obstruction: Intestinal obstruction may lead to ascites, but the fluid analysis would not typically show a high neutrophil count. The clinical presentation and history would also differ significantly, focusing more on obstructive symptoms like severe pain, vomiting, and constipation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis should be suspected in patients with chronic liver disease and ascites if the ascitic fluid neutrophil count exceeds 250 cells/mm3, necessitating prompt antibiotic treatment.

questions.text: A patient presented with follicular hyperkeratosis on the extensor aspect of the forearm. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phrynoderma

 

Phrynoderma, also known as follicular hyperkeratosis, is a skin condition commonly associated with vitamin A deficiency. It is characterized by the presence of keratotic papules, especially on extensor surfaces such as the forearms, thighs, and buttocks. The deficiency leads to abnormal keratinization of hair follicles, resulting in rough, bumpy skin, primarily affecting areas that are prone to friction or pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Darier’s disease: Darier’s disease is a genetic disorder characterized by wart-like blemishes on the body, particularly in seborrheic areas such as the scalp, forehead, chest, and back. It involves keratinization defects and does not specifically present with follicular hyperkeratosis on the extensor forearms.

 

Option C. Eruptive xanthoma: Eruptive xanthomas are yellowish papules associated with hyperlipidemia and usually occur on the buttocks, elbows, and knees. They are due to lipid deposits in the skin and do not involve follicular hyperkeratosis or specifically present on the extensor surfaces of the forearms.

 

Option D. Folliculitis: Folliculitis is an infection of the hair follicles, often presenting with small, red or pus-filled bumps. It is generally caused by bacterial infection and does not present as hyperkeratosis related to nutritional deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phrynoderma is linked to vitamin A deficiency and presents as follicular hyperkeratosis, particularly on extensor surfaces like the forearm.

choices.text: CO2 retention due to opioid use

questions.text:
A patient presented with pelvic fracture and head trauma after a road traffic accident.

He was given IV morphine for pain relief following which he developed respiratory difficulty. What could be the most likely cause? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. CO2 retention due to opioid use


The development of respiratory difficulty in a patient who received IV morphine for pain relief after sustaining a pelvic fracture and head trauma can be due to several reasons.

 

Opioids like morphine can depress the respiratory center in the brain, leading to decreased respiratory rate and tidal volume. This can result in CO2 retention and respiratory difficulty, particularly in higher doses or in patients with pre-existing respiratory issues. This is a well-known side effect of opioids and is a common cause of respiratory depression following opioid administration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pelvic Fracture: While a pelvic fracture can be severe and cause significant pain, it is not typically directly associated with the development of respiratory difficulty unless there are associated injuries, such as a pneumothorax or hemorrhage leading to shock.

 

Option C. Cerebral Edema: Head trauma can lead to cerebral edema, which in turn can affect the brain's respiratory center. However, the onset of respiratory difficulty immediately following opioid administration suggests that the opioid's effects are more likely to be the cause, rather than a progression of cerebral edema, which usually develops over a longer period.

 

Option D. Pulmonary Embolism: A pulmonary embolism (PE) is a possible complication following trauma and immobilization. However, the immediate onset of respiratory difficulty after opioid administration makes PE less likely as the primary cause in this scenario.

 

Considering the timing and circumstances, the most likely cause of the respiratory difficulty in this patient is CO2 Retention due to Opioid Use. Morphine and other opioids can cause respiratory depression, leading to reduced ventilation and CO2 retention.

 

  • The CO2 retention can also increase the ICP. Apart from that, miosis is produced by morphine, which makes it difficult for assessment of neurological status in head trauma patients. Therefore, morphine is contraindicated in head injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Opioids like morphine can cause respiratory depression by decreasing the respiratory rate and tidal volume, leading to CO2 retention. This effect is particularly concerning in patients with head trauma due to the potential for increased intracranial pressure.

questions.text: Patient came to the emergency department with 32 weeks of pregnancy with pedal edema and BP of 140/90 mmHg. Urine dipstick was 2+. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Preeclampsia

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presents with symptoms that align with the diagnosis of preeclampsia, which is characterized by the following criteria:

 

  • Elevated blood pressure (≥140/90 mmHg) after 20 weeks of gestation.
  • Proteinuria (≥1+ on dipstick or 300 mg/24 hours).

 

In this case, the patient has a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg and a urine dipstick showing 2+ proteinuria, which fits the criteria for preeclampsia. The presence of pedal edema further supports this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Abruption: This typically presents with painful vaginal bleeding and uterine tenderness. While preeclampsia can be a risk factor for abruption, the absence of vaginal bleeding in this case makes abruption less likely.

 

Option C. PPH (Postpartum Hemorrhage): This occurs after delivery and is characterized by significant bleeding post-delivery, which is not relevant in this antepartum scenario.

 

Option D. Gestational Hypertension: This is characterized by elevated blood pressure without proteinuria or other signs of preeclampsia. The presence of proteinuria in this patient rules out gestational hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Preeclampsia is diagnosed in pregnant patients presenting with hypertension and proteinuria after 20 weeks of gestation. This condition requires careful monitoring and management to prevent complications for both the mother and the fetus.

questions.text: A patient presented with the extension of MCP joint and flexion of IP joints. Which muscle is most likely affected here ? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Interossei and lumbricals

 

  • Damage to the ulnar nerve can lead to weakness or atrophy of the lumbrical and interossei muscles in the hand.
  • These muscles play a crucial role in flexing the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and extending the interphalangeal (IP) joints through their attachment to the dorsal digital expansions.
  • As a result of the nerve injury, the MCP joints may become extended, while the IP joints may become flexed.

 

Note: The ulnar nerve innervates all the intrinsic muscles of the hand, except for

 

  • First and second lumbrical
  • Abductor pollicis brevis
  • Opponens pollicis
  • Part of flexor pollicis brevis

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extensor digitorum: This muscle originates from the lateral epicondyle of the humerus and inserts into the dorsal digital expansions of the medial four fingers.

 

  • It acts primarily to extend the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and interphalangeal (IP) joints of the fingers.
  • If the extensor digitorum were affected, you would expect difficulty in extending the MCP and IP joints.

 

Option C. Abductor pollicis: 

  • It refers to two muscles, the abductor pollicis longus (located in the forearm) and abductor pollicis brevis (intrinsic hand muscle) whose primary function is to abduct the thumb. Dysfunction would primarily impact thumb movements and would not lead to the clinical picture described.

 

Option D. Abductor pollicis brevis: 

  • It is one of the thenar muscles of the hand and plays a key role in thumb movement, especially in its abduction. Like the abductor pollicis longus, an issue with this muscle would impact thumb movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Interossei and lumbricals are the intrinsic muscles of the hand.

 

  • The lumbricals arise from the tendons of the flexor digitorum profundus. They act to flex the MCP joints and extend both the proximal and distal IP joints.
  • The interossei (both dorsal and palmar) act to abduct (DAB - Dorsal Abduct) and adduct (PAD - Palmar Adduct) the fingers at the MCP joints and assist the lumbricals in flexing the MCP joints and extending the IP joints.
  • If these muscles are affected, as indicated in the clinical picture, there would be an extension of the MCP joints and flexion of the IP joints (due to unopposed action of extrinsic flexors and extensors).
